entry.title: Combined summary - BIP Proposal: Utilization of bits denomination
entry.summary: The debate about which unit of measurement to use for Bitcoin denominations has been ongoing among enthusiasts. One proposal is to use "bits" as a non-SI term for a millionth of a bitcoin, which would provide a clear and easily understandable term for users and make integration into existing financial systems easier. However, concerns have been raised about "bit" being a homonym for other words, which could lead to confusion. Some have suggested using microbitcoins instead, citing its advantages such as not being a homonym for any other word in English and training users to understand SI prefixes.Jimmy Song has proposed a BIP to standardize the term "bits" in Bitcoin transactions, while others argue that it is unnecessary and confusing. David A. Harding argues that "microbitcoins" would be a better denomination than "bits," citing its lack of homonyms and the need to train users to understand SI prefixes. He also notes that "bits" matches the format of dozens of other major currencies, which makes it superior to millibitcoins. However, the shift to "bits" will require users to train their brains by switching their wallets and exchange settings.The proposal to standardize the term "bits" in Bitcoin transactions has received mixed responses, with some supporting it as a practical solution, while others argue that it is unnecessary and confusing. The discussion includes suggestions for alternative units of measurement such as mu and finney. The decision on which unit to use will likely be influenced by linguistic network effects and user preferences.Coinbase has been using bits as the default for over 2 years, and from a linguistic standpoint, it's likely that bits will eventually become the standard. Jimmy Song's proposal defines "bits" as the standard term for 100 satoshis or 1/1,000,000 of a bitcoin. The motivation behind this proposal is that as the price of bitcoin grows, it becomes difficult to distinguish between small amounts due to the number of decimal places involved. Using "bits" instead of satoshis or milli-bitcoin makes comprehension easier and reduces user error on small amounts. Additionally, reverse comparisons are easier as it allows for easier comparisons of prices for most users and bi-directional comparisons to fiat currencies.Overall, the use of "bit" or "microbitcoin" as a denomination for Bitcoin has both practical benefits and potential drawbacks. While "bits" may be future-proofed and useful even if bitcoin prices rise significantly, a new term may be necessary if bitcoin were to soar past the $100M mark. It is important to understand when to apply one definition or the other and consider the advantages and disadvantages of each proposal.
